channel.description: Technology. Code. Living relentlessly in the real world.

item.title: Film Fight 2023: April
item.description:
The April Film Fight has five films…

Tetris

#FF23 Tetris is a decent, if somewhat compressed take, on the legal drama and backstabbing to get the rights for the game.

The cast are fine and the direction functional enough, without being interesting. It's a little too neat in places, but a perfectly fine watch.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 10, 2023

Air

#FF23 Air tells the story of the marketing drama behind getting Michael Jordan to sign with Nike.

The cast are fine, but everyone is well within their comfort zone. Similarly, Affleck as director turns in a solid enough movie, with nothing particularly flashy on camera.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 10, 2023

Operation Fortune

#FF23 Operation Fortune is a silly, slightly under budget action film.

There are some decent sequences and big, silly performances (and some that don't quite work). The plotting is a bit of a mess to get between set pieces, but that's fine.

Forgettable but fun.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 10, 2023

Shazam: Fury Of The Gods

#FF23 Shazam: Fury Of The Gods is a weaker continuation of the original.

There's no subtext (Billy's feelings are regularly stated), uneven pacing, and an eye-rolling ending made of pure fan service.

The action is fun enough, there are a few funny moments. Popcorn fodder.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 16, 2023

Assassin Club

#FF23 Assassin Club is a slog of a film.

The dialogue is absolutely leaden, the action is badly cut so as to be illegible, and the plot makes no sense. Noomi Rapace appears to be in a different movie. Sam Neill deserves better.

An action film with bad action is one to skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 16, 2023

Ghosted

#FF23 Ghosted is a light-hearted spy film, with a nonsense plot that is pretty poorly cobbled together.

There are repeated jokes about the tension between the two leads, but there is none. The music cues are genuinely terrible

There are worse things to watch but it's meh to bad

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) May 8, 2023

The April Winner

There aren’t really any gems here, and Tetris takes it by being merely okay.

item.title: Film Fight 2023: March
item.description:
Just six films in the fight this month…

Creed 3

#FF23 Creed 3 is typical of the franchise: the ups and downs of fighting someone stronger, rising to the challenge, and succeeding in some way.

The cast are all solid, the plot is predictable, and everything is watchable. The visual flair in the last act is cringeworthy.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 12, 2023

65

#FF23 65 treats it's somewhat ridiculous premise (space man crash lands on a dinosaur filled Earth) with an even tone: serious without being dour, not as a gag.

The runtime feels right, and Driver holds it together well enough. You'll see every twist coming but won't mind.

Okay

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 12, 2023

The Boston Strangler

#FF23 The Boston Strangler is a reasonable enough take on the reporting around the eponymous killer.

Both Knightley and Coon are solid as the journalists tracking down leads. It looks fine, but very generic: tealy/orange-tinged period drama.

Nothing special, but decent enough.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) March 19, 2023

John Wick: Chapter 4

#FF23 John Wick: Chapter 4 is exactly what you want in an action film.

It's a little too long, but is otherwise excellent: some of the best action and stunts in cinema, shot clearly and inventively, with a bunch of performers showing off what they can do.

Really good fun.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2023

Infinity Pool

#FF23 Infinity Pool is creeping body horror with something to say about predatorial tourism.

Goth and Skarsgård are both fully committed to their weird roles, delivering an unease that slowly ramps up. The pacing is a bit off and it doesn't get as weird as it might.

Pretty good

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2023

Women Talking

#FF23 Women Talking is disarmingly calm, for the most part, despite the horrific impetus.

A quiet conversation for 90 or so minutes, with some excellent performances from the entire cast. Despite the one major location, it remains grounded and never feels stagey.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) April 2, 2023

The March Winner

Some decent films in March, but the best film here is clearly Women Talking.

item.title: Film Fight 2023: February
item.description:
Seven films in the February Film Fight.

The Whale

#FF23 The Whale is a real mix.

Fraser is excellent in a layered performance, that is empathetic. The rest of the characters are underwritten to the point of being one note, or have bizarrely, contrived arcs. Works well in moments, but falls apart as a whole.

Meh.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 5, 2023

Bank of Dave

#FF23 Bank Of Dave is about a man trying to create a bank to help working class people.

While the fish-out-of-water jokes are tired and the romantic subplot forced, the whole thing works as a feel-good, light, underdog story. It won't win any awards, but it's easy and solid.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 13, 2023

All Quiet On The Western Front

#FF23 All Quiet On The Western Front is a protracted look at the horrors of war, and the loss of innocence.

It treads no new ground, but it covers the ground it does spectacularly and devastatingly. It makes trench warfare personal and tense, with some horrifying moments.

Great

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 13, 2023

Knock At The Cabin

#FF23 Knock At The Cabin sees Shyamalan back on form with a small, contained horror thriller that lingers in psychological doubts.

Batista is excellent as a gentle but terrifying force, delivering an apocalyptic premise. The end is heavy-handed, but the rest works well.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 13, 2023

Ant Man & The Wasp: Quantumania

#FF23 Ant Man & The Wasp: Quantumania is the blandest Marvel film in a while.

Jonathan Majors is great in his role, but the film itself is all world-building and no interesting plot or ideas. It lacks the humour and originality of the previous films.

Boring and disappointing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 26, 2023

Sharper

#FF23 Sharper does so well for a lot of its runtime, and then squanders it in the ending.

You'll see most of the cons coming, but they're executed well. The cast are excellent and make it work, but the last act requires them to become very stupid. Doesn't work.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 26, 2023

Cocaine bear

#FF23 Cocaine Bear is everything I expected it to be.

The title does most of the work: a comedic horror about a black bear finding quite a lot of coke and going on a rampage. It's over-the-top, fun, a bit silly, and a bit gory. Easy watching.

Enjoyable.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 26, 2023

The February Winner

While Cocaine Bear nearly got it for it’s simple entertainment value, I think the winner has to be All Quiet On The Western Front, a difficult but powerful watch.

item.title: Film Fight 2023: January
item.description:
A good start to the year with seven films in the fight.

The Pale Blue Eye

#FF23 The Pale Blue Eye is a decent enough thriller, following a bizarre crime and threads that don't quite match up.

The last act doesn't work, and is on the long side, but the rest is solid enough. The leads put in good performances selling the faux-supernatural elements

Okay

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 22, 2023

Empire of Light

#FF23 Empire Of Light is a love letter to the cinema experience, the racism of the 80s, mental health issues...

Its biggest problem is that it has way too many plot threads. Colman and Ward are both very good, but nothing gets a chance to breath. No subtlety either.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 22, 2023

Tár

#FF23 Tár is an excellent film styled as a biopic of a masterful, but deeply flawed, conductor.

Blanchett puts in an incredible performance, even by her own standards, with direction to match. The oner at Julliard is jaw dropping. Worth every minute of the lengthy runtime

Great

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 22, 2023

Babylon

#FF23 Babylon is a mess of a movie.

There are fun, big, extended sequences, and solid moments throughout, but nothing holds together. The cast are having fun, and it's an interesting period, but there's no real story here.

There might be a film in here if you cut an hour.

Skip

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 22, 2023

M3gan

#FF23 M3GAN is probably exactly what you expect if you've seen a trailer.

A fun, light horror about an increasingly dangerous doll, like Child's Play. It's entertaining, well made, and more than a bit silly. Williams does well in finding the right tone.

Fun.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 29, 2023

The Fabelmans

#FF23 The Fabelmans is a light biopic of Spielberg's barely-disguised upbringing.

The cast are excellent, particularly Monaghan as the artistic, flighty mother. Throughout we see the awe Sammy does in the world of film, but without much weight.

Okay, but toothless.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 29, 2023

Aftersun

#FF23 Aftersun follows a father and daughter on a 90s holiday.

Its true marvel is there's no dark narrative drama. It just shows an honest slice of a relationship, with great, naturalistic performances. It captures the feel of a home movie, intercutting DV footage.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) February 5, 2023

The January Winner

Despite some very good films, this is an easy win for Tár: incredible performances, good drama, gorgeous film.

item.title: Film Fight 2021: Finale
item.description:
Another year of film watching done. Back to the cinema for a lot of this, but also a bunch that were first/early release at home. Seems like a lot of low to mid budget films are skipping cinemas entirely these days.

As per the caveat every year, Film Fight is done in a (non particularly serious) knock-out style: it can pick my favourite film of the year, but nothing else. (Also the very idea of a single favourite film is a bit silly.)

First up is the honorable mentions: films that weren’t good enough to win their own month, but still worth seeing.

  • Licorice Pizza
  • Swan Song
  • The Eyes Of Tammy Faye
  • Petite Maman
  • Belfast
  • Lamb
  • The Tragedy Of Macbeth
  • After Yang
  • Titane
  • The Northman
  • All The Old Knives
  • Emergency
  • Pleasure
  • Top Gun: Maverick
  • Nope
  • Rogue Agent
  • Three Thousand Years of Longing
  • I Came By
  • The Woman King
  • The Banshees Of Inisherin
  • Emily The Criminal
  • Clerks III
  • The Menu
  • The Wonder
  • Bones And All
  • The Stranger
  • She Said
  • Glass Onion
  • Corsage

And now the monthly winners:

  • January: The Lost Daughter
  • February: CODA
  • March: Kimi
  • April: Mass
  • May: Everything Everywhere All At Once
  • June: Men
  • July: Thor: Love And Thunder (no, I wasn’t happy about it either)
  • August: Prey
  • September: The Forgiven
  • October: Barbarian
  • November: Pearl
  • December: Decision To Leave

We have a decent enough list of winners with only July really letting the side down.

CODA and Mass were excellent character and performance driven films, with important but very different messages.

There’s more horror on the list than in previous years, with Barbarian being the best of three, but Pearl being pretty close, especially for that monologue at the end. Men was fine, but I don’t see myself going back to it much.

The Forgiven and Decision To Leave have you sitting in a feeling considering what you might do in this situation, which makes for great, lingering cinema.

I’m quite torn. I saw Decision To Leave a few days ago so it’s still quite fresh, but I also remember the fairly emotional experiences of watching CODA and Mass.

I think I’m going with Mass as my film of 2022. It’s a simple setup, mostly four people in one room talking about a tragedy, but you feel every bit of it.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: December
item.description:
For December, we have 9 films in the fight!

Violent Night

#FF22 Violent Night tries to make a festive John Wick, and doesn't quite manage.

A fun premise but, despite some enjoyable moments, the action doesn't really work: way too many cuts, and under-lit scenes for it to be slick. Harbour is solid enough.

Okay but largely forgettable

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 4, 2022

The Stranger

#FF22 The Stranger is a slow, unnerving film that slowly lets you in on the horrendous case hidden behind the immediate narrative.

Both Harris and Edgerton are good, as the creepy con and undercover cop. A very slow burn, as we start to understand the scope.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 4, 2022

She Said

#FF22 She Said is about the investigative journalists who break the Weinstein story.

It's very straightforward, and fast-paced; constantly moving to the next lead. It focuses, rightly, on the women impacted, including the journalists. Good central performances.

Worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 11, 2022

The Infernal Machine

#FF22 The Infernal Machine is pretty dull and slow.

Pierce is fine as the lead, but he's not given a lot to go on. The twists are either very signposted or absolutely baffling, including the cut-rate Stephen King ending.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 30, 2022

Glass Onion

#FF22 Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery is fun, if lightweight, entertainment.

The entire cast is great, especially Monae and Craig; mostly playing unlikeable, vain people. The structure works well, with some neat twists hidden in plain sight.

Enjoyable.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 30, 2022

Corsage

#FF22 Corsage is a slow but very watchable look at rejecting what's expected of you, while still needing others.

Vicki Krieps is excellent as the lead (an Austrian Empress). The whole thing looks great, with the interesting choice of non-period elements coming through.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 7, 2023

It’s A Wonderful Binge

#FF22 It's A Wonderful Binge is genuinely terrible.

Where the first one was stupid but fun, this is just an incoherent mess; none of the main threads really work or come together. Few if any funny moments. Kaitlin Olson is better than this.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 7, 2023

White Noise

#FF22 White Noise is turgidly slow, and lacks .

It tries an affect somewhere between the Coens and Wes Anderson, failing entirely. The dialogue is read in the same flat way by every character. The few good moments don't save it.

Surprisingly bad, given the cast and director.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 7, 2023

Decision to Leave

#FF22 Decision To Leave is another masterpiece by Park Chan-wook.

The story and imagery constantly brings us back to the themes (failing love, new love, betrayal etc), showing us everything from fresh perspectives.

Melancholy, but stunningly executed. Will stay with you.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) January 7, 2023

The December Winner

The December winner is the excellent Decision To Leave, largely for the reason stated: you’re not going to forget this soon.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: November
item.description:
A busy month with 10 films in the fight.

Vengeance

#FF22 Vengeance follows a self-involved podcaster spending time with a down to Earth family to solve something.

It plays into the fish out of water comedy a little much, but hits in other places. The cast and pacing are solid, and there are nice moments.

Ultimately, good fun.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 6, 2022

Clerks III

#FF22 Clerks III is Kevin Smith's best work in years.

There are places where it's underbaked and pandering (and indulges its meta-ness), but it tells a solid story about friendship and growing up while taking the series back to its roots.

Surprisingly good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 6, 2022

Smile

#FF22 Smile is the kind of horror that doesn't work.

It fails because it takes no time to make you empathetic to the main character and has smart people act in very stupid ways. The fake outs are tiresome. There are cheap but admittedly effective jump scares throughout.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 13, 2022

Black Panther: Wakanda Forever

#FF22 Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a mixed bag.

Beautiful production design throughout, Namor and his people are standouts. The action is great in places, and muddled in others. Solid plot and themes but Wright is the weakest link in an otherwise very good cast.

Okay.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 13, 2022

Pearl

#FF22 Pearl is horror at its best: doing something different, confidently, and pulling it off.

It's showy, but it all lands: from the bright production design, the musical moments, the bold camera work. None more so than Mia Goth's jaw droppingly good monologue.

A must see.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 20, 2022

The Menu

#FF22 The Menu is dark satire, taking aim at the pretentious world of high-end dining.

Delightful performances throughout (especially Hong Chau's Elsa) accompany a solid story. While it does get predictable towards the end, the journey is good enough.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 20, 2022

Confess, Fletch

#FF22 Confess, Fletch sees John Hamm as the lead in a bit of a shaggy dog story.

The plot itself doesn't hold up to much scrutiny, but the film is enjoyable enough as a silly, dry comedy with some decent lines and twists.

Pleasant and watchable enough.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) November 20, 2022

The Wonder

#FF22 The Wonder is a smart, mostly quiet film about belief and the stories we tell ourselves.

Pugh is excellent as the steadfast nurse investigating a child who supposedly hasn't eaten in months. Well-paced, if a little obvious, with beautiful moments throughout.

Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 4, 2022

Bones And All

#FF22 Bones And All is enjoyably gruesome horror.

Shot and setup like a young adult romance, which works to contrast the creepiness of the cannibal subculture.

Doesn't quite nail the ending, but has a lot of great moments along the way, with both leads doing a solid job.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 4, 2022

Watcher

#FF22 Watcher fails to amount to much of anything.

The lonely, isolated woman who might be imagining things has been done to death, with nothing new offered here. Slow, and unoriginal.

Skip.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) December 4, 2022

The November Winner

Some very good films in November, but I think the winner is Pearl for so many moments, but mostly for that monologue.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: October
item.description:
A busy month with 10 new films…

Don’t Worry Darling

#FF22 Don't Worry Darling is an entertaining mess of a film.

The production design and general look of the film is top notch, with real Bioshock vibes. Florence Pugh, too, is excellent. The twist is predictable, but aspects of it are eye-rollingly bad.

Good enough, but light.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 2, 2022

Hatching

#FF22 Hatching is a fun, if at sometimes, silly horror.

A young, Finnish girl rescues a motherless egg, and in the process creates something creepy. The performances and pacing are solid, but there's very little subtext here; everything is pretty clear.

Good enough.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 16, 2022

The Woman King

#FF22 The Woman King is an excellent, historical action film, with a great cast.

One light romantic subplot aside, the various threads all work well. The film fleshes out its characters fully, beyond just being incredibly tough women. Looks fantastic too.

Great action film.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 16, 2022

Luckiest Girl Alive

#FF22 Luckiest Girl Alive is a bit of mess.

It jumps into heavy-handed narration, that tells rather than shows, and has some very out of place moments. There are a few scenes with appropriate weight, but they're the exception. Tonally all over the place.

Fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 16, 2022

No Exit

#FF22 No Exit knows what it is: a lightweight, low-runtime, strangers in a cabin horror-thriller. On that level, it works.

The film won't surprise you much, the strokes being used here are broad, but it does its thing well. There are a handful of well-done gruesome moments.

Ok

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 16, 2022

Amsterdam

#FF22 Amsterdam is a mess on all levels.

An incredible cast who are tonally in different films; a meandering plot with leaden pacing; showy direction that distracts; horrible structure with intermittent narration; and wildly unnatural dialogue.

Some funny lines, but pretty bad.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 16, 2022

The Banshees of Inisherin

#FF22 The Banshees Of Inisherin is a bleak, black comedy in the vein of McDonagh's other works.

The performances here work well, espcially Farrell's nice but dim farmer and Gleeson's dour and uptight musician. Some difficult moments punctuated with real laughs.

Well executed.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 30, 2022

Emily The Criminal

#FF22 Emily The Criminal sees Aubrey Plaza go from petty criminal to something bigger, as her circumstances (and attitude) force her towards wider confrontation.

Fun, clear plotting, and a solid cast make this a relatively easy to watch drama.

Good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 30, 2022

The Innocents

#FF22 The Innocents is a Scandinavian horror about some very young kids with difficulties, who gain growing powers.

There are some very difficult to watch scenes in here and the last act drags, but there's a creeping dread throughout that makes this compelling.

Decent.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 30, 2022

Barbarian

#FF22 Barbarian is about a woman who finds her AirBnB is already occupied but quickly realises that's not her biggest problem.

The pacing here is excellent with several switches in context as we learn more about what's happening. Fantastic direction.

An excellent, modern horror

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 30, 2022

The October Winner

Some very good options but I’m going with Barbarian as the kind of horror I love: it’s inventive, and constantly shifting.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: September
item.description:
Nine films for the September Film Fight!

Rogue Agent

#FF22 Rogue Agent starts with the worst kind of narration; all tell and now show.

It picks up significantly, as it moves into the main story of a charismatic con man. Arterton is excellent, as usual, and Norton makes the whole thing work.

Well paced, clear stakes, worth seeing.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 10, 2022

Three Thousand Years Of Longing

#FF22 Three Thousand Years Of Longing is intriguingly small, yet expansive.

Set mostly in a room with an academic and a Djinn going back and forward, hearing stories that might be true or a trick. Swinton and Elba lack chemistry, but it doesn't matter.

Enjoyable, but flawed.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 10, 2022

The Forgiven

#FF22 The Forgiven doesn't linger long on its precipitating event, quickly going to considerations and consequences.

The cast is strong, split between the cartoonishly rich and grounded poverty; the film builds on the juxtaposition.

Dark humour, drama, and tragedy. Very good.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 10, 2022

Fall

#FF22 Fall is an okay story of two women being stuck 2000ft up a TV tower.

It doesn't earn its twists (which are telegraphed) and the budget shows through at times, but it does it's job of making you jump at just the right moment.

Okay, but lightweight.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 10, 2022

Bodies Bodies Bodies

#FF22 Bodies Bodies Bodies is a tight little slasher, that encapsulates the Werewolf/Among Us experience well.

Maybe a little predictable but fun. Doesn’t outstay it’s welcome.

Perfect popcorn fodder.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 11, 2022

See How They Run

#FF22 See How They Run tries to spoof Agatha Christie, but comes across as a little self-satisfied.

It all feels underwritten, with a great cast delivering lines flatly; failing to find the comedy in the farce. The structure and callbacks are painfully obvious.

Forgettable.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 24, 2022

Funny Pages

#FF22 Funny Pages sees a young cartoonist, obsessed with the likes of Robert Crumb, devolve his life into the kind of low-life world he sees in comics.

Like a Solondz film but without the bite, the plot sprawls but rarely progresses. A little twisted and funny, but also hollow.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) September 24, 2022

Crimes Of The Future

#FF22 Crimes Of The Future is Cronenberg returning to his body horror roots, with an eco-tinged story of squirming surgery as art.

Solid leads, but the story is muddled and meandering, with languid pacing.

Disturbing in places, leering in others. Uncomfortable, as is the point.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 2, 2022

I Came By

#FF22 I Came By is a horror thriller, billed as a home invasion but is actually something... different.

The four leads are excellent, taking their turn in the spotlight as the plot twists, and twist it does. It never quite works out how you expect; a rare thing these days.

Good

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) October 2, 2022

The September Winner

Not a bad month, but not a great one either; lots of solid films, but not much that’s great. I think the winner is The Forgiven for walking quite a difficult path and pulling it off.

item.title: Film Fight 2022: August
item.description:
A short month with only 4 films…

Bullet Train

#FF22 Bullet Train is a fine if somewhat forgettable entry into the overstylized action genre.

People have codenames that appear onscreen, we jump around the timeline, the dialogue is snappy: you've seen this before.

Entertaining enough action. Generally fine.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 7, 2022

Prey

#FF22 Prey is an excellent entry in the Predator franchise.

Beautifully shot, well-paced, tense, brutal action. Midthunder is fantastic as the lead, bringing tenacity and vulnerability to the role.

Original and exciting, while bringing back the ethos of the original.

Must see.

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 7, 2022

Nope

#FF22 Nope defies neat explanations and simple categorisation.

The cast are strong and it looks great, with the main action being clear and focussed. That recurring sequence in the TV studio is superbly tense. The message is harder to extract.

Enjoyable, but not straightforward

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 20, 2022

Day Shift

#FF22 Day Shift starts with a solid, quiet action scene that sets the world up neatly...

...and quickly devolves. While the action remains decent, the plot is nonsense and most of the characters don't make sense; world-stuffing the film for a franchise.

Forgettably entertaining

— Gary Fleming (@garyfleming) August 21, 2022

The August Winner

While Nope is interesting, Prey has to be the winner: a great action film that rejuvenates a flagging franchise.
